conclusion: Introduction to the problem with two hemispheres A and B, their masses, and friction conditions.
Understanding that the hemispheres are in equilibrium and frictional force is at its maximum.
Plan to analyze forces acting on each hemisphere, starting with hemisphere B.
Hemisphere B has a mass of 2m and is smooth, meaning no friction with hemisphere A.
The line connecting the centers of the hemispheres makes a 30° angle with the horizontal.
Forces on hemisphere B: weight 2mg downward, normal force F along the line at 30°, normal force FN horizontally.
Equilibrium condition for hemisphere B: FN - F cos(30°) = 0 and F sin(30°) - 2mg = 0.
Calculate F from vertical equilibrium: F = 4mg.
Calculate FN from horizontal equilibrium: FN = 2mg√3.
Plan to analyze forces on hemisphere A.
Hemisphere A has a mass of m, and there's friction with the left wall.
Forces on hemisphere A: weight mg downward, normal force FN1 horizontally, frictional force Ff upward, normal force from B is 4mg.
Equilibrium condition for hemisphere A: FN1 - F cos(30°) = 0 and F sin(30°) + Ff - mg = 0.
Attempt to calculate Ff: Ff = -mg, realizing a mistake.
